_link.title: I can compare the energy released by nuclear reactions versus chemical reactions

toLevel2.question: Approximately how many times more energy per kilogram do nuclear reactions release compared to chemical reactions?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Nuclear reactions release approximately one million (10⁶) times more energy per kilogram than chemical reactions due to the strength of nuclear forces.

distractors.explanation: Nuclear reactions release approximately one million (10⁶) times more energy per kilogram than chemical reactions due to the strength of nuclear forces.
Nuclear reactions release approximately one million (10⁶) times more energy per kilogram than chemical reactions due to the strength of nuclear forces.
Nuclear reactions release approximately one million (10⁶) times more energy per kilogram than chemical reactions due to the strength of nuclear forces.

toLevel2.question: Why do nuclear reactions release so much more energy than chemical reactions?
toLevel2.correct: The strong nuclear force is much stronger than electromagnetic forces
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong nuclear force binding nucleons together is far stronger than the electromagnetic forces binding electrons, resulting in much larger energy changes.

distractors.answer: Nuclear fuels are denser than chemical fuels
distractors.explanation: The strong nuclear force binding nucleons together is far stronger than the electromagnetic forces binding electrons, resulting in much larger energy changes.

distractors.answer: Nuclear reactions occur at higher temperatures
distractors.explanation: The strong nuclear force binding nucleons together is far stronger than the electromagnetic forces binding electrons, resulting in much larger energy changes.

distractors.answer: Chemical reactions lose energy as heat
distractors.explanation: The strong nuclear force binding nucleons together is far stronger than the electromagnetic forces binding electrons, resulting in much larger energy changes.

toLevel2.question: What type of particles are involved in chemical reactions?
toLevel2.correct: Electrons in the outer shells of atoms
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Chemical reactions involve the rearrangement of electrons between atoms, while the nucleus remains unchanged.

distractors.answer: Protons and neutrons in the nucleus
distractors.explanation: Chemical reactions involve the rearrangement of electrons between atoms, while the nucleus remains unchanged.
Chemical reactions involve the rearrangement of electrons between atoms, while the nucleus remains unchanged.
Chemical reactions involve the rearrangement of electrons between atoms, while the nucleus remains unchanged.

toLevel2.question: What is the approximate energy released per kilogram when burning coal?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Coal releases about 30 million joules (3 × 10⁷ J) per kilogram when burned, typical for chemical reactions.

distractors.explanation: Coal releases about 30 million joules (3 × 10⁷ J) per kilogram when burned, typical for chemical reactions.
Coal releases about 30 million joules (3 × 10⁷ J) per kilogram when burned, typical for chemical reactions.
Coal releases about 30 million joules (3 × 10⁷ J) per kilogram when burned, typical for chemical reactions.

toLevel2.question: How much energy is released per kilogram from uranium fission?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Uranium fission releases about 80 trillion joules (8 × 10¹³ J) per kilogram, roughly a million times more than coal.

distractors.explanation: Uranium fission releases about 80 trillion joules (8 × 10¹³ J) per kilogram, roughly a million times more than coal.
Uranium fission releases about 80 trillion joules (8 × 10¹³ J) per kilogram, roughly a million times more than coal.
Uranium fission releases about 80 trillion joules (8 × 10¹³ J) per kilogram, roughly a million times more than coal.

toLevel2.sentence: Nuclear reactions release about one {{blank:1}} times more energy than {{blank:2}} reactions per kilogram of fuel.

1.correctExplanation: The energy density of nuclear fuel is approximately one million times greater than chemical fuels due to nuclear force strength.

distractors.explanation: The energy density of nuclear fuel is approximately one million times greater than chemical fuels due to nuclear force strength.
The energy density of nuclear fuel is approximately one million times greater than chemical fuels due to nuclear force strength.

The energy density of nuclear fuel is approximately one million times greater than chemical fuels due to nuclear force strength.

toLevel2.sentence: Chemical reactions involve {{blank:1}} rearrangement, while nuclear reactions involve changes to the {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: Chemical reactions only change electron arrangements; nuclear reactions change the composition of atomic nuclei.

distractors.explanation: Chemical reactions only change electron arrangements; nuclear reactions change the composition of atomic nuclei.
Chemical reactions only change electron arrangements; nuclear reactions change the composition of atomic nuclei.

toLevel2.sentence: The {{blank:1}} force holds nucleons together and is much stronger than the {{blank:2}} force binding electrons.

1.correctExplanation: The strong nuclear force is about 137 times stronger than the electromagnetic force, explaining nuclear energy's enormous density.

distractors.explanation: The strong nuclear force is about 137 times stronger than the electromagnetic force, explaining nuclear energy's enormous density.
The strong nuclear force is about 137 times stronger than the electromagnetic force, explaining nuclear energy's enormous density.

toLevel2.question: A small uranium pellet can release as much energy as burning a tonne of coal.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: True. Due to the million-fold energy density difference, a few grams of uranium can match a tonne of coal's energy output.

distractors.explanation: True. Due to the million-fold energy density difference, a few grams of uranium can match a tonne of coal's energy output.

toLevel2.question: Chemical reactions release more energy per atom than nuclear reactions.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: False. Nuclear reactions release millions of times more energy per atom than chemical reactions.

distractors.explanation: False. Nuclear reactions release millions of times more energy per atom than chemical reactions.

toLevel3.question: Why do chemical reactions not involve changes to the atomic nucleus?
toLevel3.correct: The energy available in chemical reactions is too low to overcome nuclear binding energy
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Chemical reaction energies (few eV) are far too small to overcome nuclear binding energies (MeV range), leaving nuclei unaffected.

distractors.answer: Chemical elements cannot undergo nuclear changes
distractors.explanation: Chemical reaction energies (few eV) are far too small to overcome nuclear binding energies (MeV range), leaving nuclei unaffected.

distractors.answer: Nuclei do not exist in chemical reactions
distractors.explanation: Chemical reaction energies (few eV) are far too small to overcome nuclear binding energies (MeV range), leaving nuclei unaffected.

distractors.answer: Chemical reactions are too slow to affect nuclei
distractors.explanation: Chemical reaction energies (few eV) are far too small to overcome nuclear binding energies (MeV range), leaving nuclei unaffected.

toLevel3.question: How does the energy per reaction event compare between burning coal and uranium fission?
toLevel3.correct: Fission releases about 200 MeV versus about 4 eV for combustion
toLevel3.correctExplanation: A single uranium fission releases about 200 MeV, while burning one carbon atom releases only about 4 eV—a factor of 50 million difference.

distractors.answer: Both release similar amounts of energy
distractors.explanation: A single uranium fission releases about 200 MeV, while burning one carbon atom releases only about 4 eV—a factor of 50 million difference.

distractors.answer: Combustion releases more energy per event
distractors.explanation: A single uranium fission releases about 200 MeV, while burning one carbon atom releases only about 4 eV—a factor of 50 million difference.

distractors.answer: Fission releases about 4 MeV versus 200 eV for combustion
distractors.explanation: A single uranium fission releases about 200 MeV, while burning one carbon atom releases only about 4 eV—a factor of 50 million difference.

toLevel3.question: Why is the strong nuclear force so much stronger than electromagnetic forces?
toLevel3.correct: It acts over very short ranges with much greater intensity
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The strong force is about 137 times stronger than electromagnetism but only acts over nuclear distances (~10⁻¹⁵ m), making it short-range but intense.

distractors.explanation: The strong force is about 137 times stronger than electromagnetism but only acts over nuclear distances (~10⁻¹⁵ m), making it short-range but intense.
The strong force is about 137 times stronger than electromagnetism but only acts over nuclear distances (~10⁻¹⁵ m), making it short-range but intense.
The strong force is about 137 times stronger than electromagnetism but only acts over nuclear distances (~10⁻¹⁵ m), making it short-range but intense.

toLevel3.question: What fundamental difference explains why mass is conserved in chemical reactions but not in nuclear reactions?
toLevel3.correct: Chemical energy changes are too small to cause measurable mass changes
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Mass-energy equivalence applies to both, but chemical energy changes (eV) correspond to unmeasurably tiny mass changes, unlike nuclear reactions (MeV).

distractors.answer: Mass is always conserved in all reactions
distractors.explanation: Mass-energy equivalence applies to both, but chemical energy changes (eV) correspond to unmeasurably tiny mass changes, unlike nuclear reactions (MeV).
Mass-energy equivalence applies to both, but chemical energy changes (eV) correspond to unmeasurably tiny mass changes, unlike nuclear reactions (MeV).
Mass-energy equivalence applies to both, but chemical energy changes (eV) correspond to unmeasurably tiny mass changes, unlike nuclear reactions (MeV).

toLevel3.question: Why are the products of chemical reactions the same elements as the reactants?
toLevel3.correct: Only electrons rearrange; protons and neutrons remain unchanged
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Chemical reactions only rearrange electrons between atoms. Since proton number determines the element and nuclei don't change, elements are conserved.

distractors.answer: Chemical reactions cannot create or destroy matter
distractors.explanation: Chemical reactions only rearrange electrons between atoms. Since proton number determines the element and nuclei don't change, elements are conserved.
Chemical reactions only rearrange electrons between atoms. Since proton number determines the element and nuclei don't change, elements are conserved.

distractors.answer: Chemical bonds are too strong to break atoms
distractors.explanation: Chemical reactions only rearrange electrons between atoms. Since proton number determines the element and nuclei don't change, elements are conserved.

toLevel3.question: How does energy density relate to the amount of fuel needed for a given power output?
toLevel3.correct: Higher energy density means less fuel is needed for the same energy
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Energy density (energy per unit mass) determines fuel efficiency. Nuclear's million-fold advantage means vastly less fuel is needed.

distractors.answer: Energy density has no effect on fuel consumption
distractors.explanation: Energy density (energy per unit mass) determines fuel efficiency. Nuclear's million-fold advantage means vastly less fuel is needed.

distractors.answer: Higher energy density requires more fuel
distractors.explanation: Energy density (energy per unit mass) determines fuel efficiency. Nuclear's million-fold advantage means vastly less fuel is needed.

distractors.answer: Only nuclear fuels have energy density
distractors.explanation: Energy density (energy per unit mass) determines fuel efficiency. Nuclear's million-fold advantage means vastly less fuel is needed.

toLevel3.question: The mass change in chemical reactions is so small that it cannot be measured with current technology.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: True. Chemical energy changes of a few eV correspond to mass changes of ~10⁻³⁶ kg per atom, far below any measurement capability.

toLevel4.question: A power station needs to generate 1 GW continuously. Calculate the approximate daily coal consumption compared to uranium consumption.
toLevel4.correct: About 8,600 tonnes of coal versus about 3 kg of uranium

distractors.answer: About 860 tonnes of coal versus about 30 kg of uranium
About 86 tonnes of coal versus about 300 g of uranium
About equal amounts of each fuel

toLevel4.question: If a uranium pellet (10 g) releases 8 × 10¹¹ J, how much coal would be needed to release the same energy?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Coal energy: 3 × 10⁷ J/kg. Mass needed: 8 × 10¹¹ / 3 × 10⁷ = 2.7 × 10⁴ kg = 27 tonnes.

distractors.explanation: Coal energy: 3 × 10⁷ J/kg. Mass needed: 8 × 10¹¹ / 3 × 10⁷ = 2.7 × 10⁴ kg = 27 tonnes.

toLevel4.question: Calculate the ratio of energy released from 1 kg of uranium to 1 kg of coal.

distractors.explanation: Ratio = (8 × 10¹³ J/kg) / (3 × 10⁷ J/kg) = 2.7 × 10⁶ (about 2.7 million).
Ratio = (8 × 10¹³ J/kg) / (3 × 10⁷ J/kg) = 2.7 × 10⁶ (about 2.7 million).

toLevel4.question: A city needs 100 TJ of energy per day. Compare the fuel requirements for nuclear versus coal power.
toLevel4.correct: About 1.25 kg uranium versus 3,300 tonnes coal
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Uranium: 10¹⁴ J / 8 × 10¹³ J/kg ≈ 1.25 kg. Coal: 10¹⁴ J / 3 × 10⁷ J/kg ≈ 3.3 × 10⁶ kg = 3,300 tonnes.

distractors.answer: About 12.5 kg uranium versus 330 tonnes coal
distractors.explanation: Uranium: 10¹⁴ J / 8 × 10¹³ J/kg ≈ 1.25 kg. Coal: 10¹⁴ J / 3 × 10⁷ J/kg ≈ 3.3 × 10⁶ kg = 3,300 tonnes.

distractors.answer: About 125 kg uranium versus 33 tonnes coal
distractors.explanation: Uranium: 10¹⁴ J / 8 × 10¹³ J/kg ≈ 1.25 kg. Coal: 10¹⁴ J / 3 × 10⁷ J/kg ≈ 3.3 × 10⁶ kg = 3,300 tonnes.

toLevel4.question: If electricity costs are proportional to fuel mass transported, how much cheaper would nuclear fuel transportation be?
toLevel4.correct: About one million times cheaper per unit energy
toLevel4.correctExplanation: With energy density ratio of about 10⁶, transporting fuel for nuclear is about a million times cheaper per unit energy delivered.

distractors.explanation: With energy density ratio of about 10⁶, transporting fuel for nuclear is about a million times cheaper per unit energy delivered.

toLevel4.question: A household uses 20 kWh of electricity per day. How much uranium fission would supply their annual needs?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Annual energy: 20 kWh × 365 = 7,300 kWh = 2.6 × 10¹⁰ J. Uranium needed: 2.6 × 10¹⁰ / 8 × 10¹³ ≈ 0.3 g ≈ 1 gram.

distractors.explanation: Annual energy: 20 kWh × 365 = 7,300 kWh = 2.6 × 10¹⁰ J. Uranium needed: 2.6 × 10¹⁰ / 8 × 10¹³ ≈ 0.3 g ≈ 1 gram.

toLevel4.question: Why can nuclear submarines operate for years without refueling while conventional ships need frequent fuel stops?
toLevel4.correct: Nuclear fuel's million-fold energy density allows years of operation from a small reactor core
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The enormous energy density of nuclear fuel allows submarines to carry enough fuel for 20+ years of operation in a compact reactor.

distractors.explanation: The enormous energy density of nuclear fuel allows submarines to carry enough fuel for 20+ years of operation in a compact reactor.

distractors.answer: Submarines use less energy than ships

toLevel5.question: Analyze why the energy difference between nuclear and chemical reactions is exactly related to the relative strengths of fundamental forces.
toLevel5.correct: Binding energies depend directly on force strength, with strong force being millions of times stronger at nuclear scales
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Bond energies directly reflect force strengths. The strong nuclear force at 10⁻¹⁵ m is ~10⁶ times stronger than electromagnetism at atomic scales (10⁻¹⁰ m).

distractors.answer: The forces operate independently of energy
distractors.explanation: Bond energies directly reflect force strengths. The strong nuclear force at 10⁻¹⁵ m is ~10⁶ times stronger than electromagnetism at atomic scales (10⁻¹⁰ m).

distractors.answer: Chemical and nuclear forces are the same force at different scales
distractors.explanation: Bond energies directly reflect force strengths. The strong nuclear force at 10⁻¹⁵ m is ~10⁶ times stronger than electromagnetism at atomic scales (10⁻¹⁰ m).
Bond energies directly reflect force strengths. The strong nuclear force at 10⁻¹⁵ m is ~10⁶ times stronger than electromagnetism at atomic scales (10⁻¹⁰ m).

toLevel5.question: Evaluate why comparing energy per kilogram is more meaningful than energy per reaction for practical applications.
toLevel5.correct: Practical systems handle macroscopic fuel quantities, making mass-based comparisons relevant for planning
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Engineers plan fuel supply, storage, and transport in mass units. Energy density (J/kg) directly determines infrastructure requirements.

distractors.answer: Energy per reaction is impossible to measure
distractors.explanation: Engineers plan fuel supply, storage, and transport in mass units. Energy density (J/kg) directly determines infrastructure requirements.
Engineers plan fuel supply, storage, and transport in mass units. Energy density (J/kg) directly determines infrastructure requirements.

distractors.answer: All fuels have the same molecular weight
distractors.explanation: Engineers plan fuel supply, storage, and transport in mass units. Energy density (J/kg) directly determines infrastructure requirements.

toLevel5.question: Why does nuclear energy's advantage over chemical energy have implications for space travel?
toLevel5.correct: The mass savings from higher energy density are crucial when every kilogram of fuel must be launched
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Launching fuel is expensive (~$10,000/kg to orbit). Nuclear's million-fold energy advantage makes it attractive for long-duration space missions.

distractors.answer: Nuclear reactions work better in zero gravity
distractors.explanation: Launching fuel is expensive (~$10,000/kg to orbit). Nuclear's million-fold energy advantage makes it attractive for long-duration space missions.

distractors.answer: Chemical rockets cannot escape Earth's atmosphere
distractors.explanation: Launching fuel is expensive (~$10,000/kg to orbit). Nuclear's million-fold energy advantage makes it attractive for long-duration space missions.

distractors.answer: Space agencies prefer nuclear power for political reasons
distractors.explanation: Launching fuel is expensive (~$10,000/kg to orbit). Nuclear's million-fold energy advantage makes it attractive for long-duration space missions.

toLevel5.question: Compare the environmental footprint per unit energy between coal and nuclear power, considering fuel extraction and transport.
toLevel5.correct: Nuclear requires vastly less mining and transport per unit energy, reducing land disturbance
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Mining 3 kg of uranium versus 27,000 tonnes of coal for the same energy means nuclear has far less mining impact, transport emissions, and land disturbance.

distractors.answer: Coal has a smaller footprint because it's natural
distractors.explanation: Mining 3 kg of uranium versus 27,000 tonnes of coal for the same energy means nuclear has far less mining impact, transport emissions, and land disturbance.
Mining 3 kg of uranium versus 27,000 tonnes of coal for the same energy means nuclear has far less mining impact, transport emissions, and land disturbance.

distractors.answer: Nuclear mining disturbs more land than coal mining
distractors.explanation: Mining 3 kg of uranium versus 27,000 tonnes of coal for the same energy means nuclear has far less mining impact, transport emissions, and land disturbance.

toLevel5.question: How does the energy comparison inform decisions about future energy infrastructure?
toLevel5.correct: Nuclear's compact energy source suits baseload power but chemical flexibility serves different needs
toLevel5.correctExplanation: High energy density favors nuclear for steady baseload power. Chemical fuels offer storage, portability, and flexibility advantages for transport and peak demand.

distractors.answer: The comparison proves nuclear is always better
distractors.explanation: High energy density favors nuclear for steady baseload power. Chemical fuels offer storage, portability, and flexibility advantages for transport and peak demand.

distractors.answer: Chemical fuels should be completely abandoned
distractors.explanation: High energy density favors nuclear for steady baseload power. Chemical fuels offer storage, portability, and flexibility advantages for transport and peak demand.

distractors.answer: Energy density is irrelevant to infrastructure planning
distractors.explanation: High energy density favors nuclear for steady baseload power. Chemical fuels offer storage, portability, and flexibility advantages for transport and peak demand.

toLevel5.question: Analyze why fission energy is 'only' 10⁶ times greater than chemical energy, not 10⁸ as the force ratio might suggest.
toLevel5.correct: Only a fraction of nuclear mass converts to energy, while chemical bonds have larger spatial extent
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Nuclear fission converts only ~0.1% of mass to energy. Additionally, chemical bonds, though weaker, involve larger electron cloud volumes, partially compensating.

distractors.explanation: Nuclear fission converts only ~0.1% of mass to energy. Additionally, chemical bonds, though weaker, involve larger electron cloud volumes, partially compensating.

distractors.answer: Nuclear forces are weaker than assumed
distractors.explanation: Nuclear fission converts only ~0.1% of mass to energy. Additionally, chemical bonds, though weaker, involve larger electron cloud volumes, partially compensating.

distractors.answer: Chemical reactions are more efficient than expected
distractors.explanation: Nuclear fission converts only ~0.1% of mass to energy. Additionally, chemical bonds, though weaker, involve larger electron cloud volumes, partially compensating.

toLevel5.question: Why is the nuclear-chemical energy comparison particularly relevant to climate change discussions?
toLevel5.correct: Nuclear's energy density means far less fuel extraction, transport, and waste per unit energy with zero carbon emissions
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Nuclear's zero carbon emissions during operation, combined with minimal fuel requirements, make it attractive for decarbonizing electricity generation.

distractors.answer: Chemical fuels don't contribute to climate change
distractors.explanation: Nuclear's zero carbon emissions during operation, combined with minimal fuel requirements, make it attractive for decarbonizing electricity generation.

distractors.answer: Nuclear power produces more greenhouse gases
distractors.explanation: Nuclear's zero carbon emissions during operation, combined with minimal fuel requirements, make it attractive for decarbonizing electricity generation.

distractors.answer: The comparison is not relevant to climate discussions
distractors.explanation: Nuclear's zero carbon emissions during operation, combined with minimal fuel requirements, make it attractive for decarbonizing electricity generation.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate how the energy density difference affects national energy security and independence.
toLevel5.correct: A nation can stockpile years of nuclear fuel in a small space, reducing vulnerability to supply disruptions
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Small volumes of nuclear fuel can meet years of energy needs, making strategic reserves practical. Coal's bulk makes equivalent stockpiling impractical.

distractors.answer: Energy density has no security implications
distractors.explanation: Small volumes of nuclear fuel can meet years of energy needs, making strategic reserves practical. Coal's bulk makes equivalent stockpiling impractical.

distractors.answer: Coal provides better energy security than nuclear
distractors.explanation: Small volumes of nuclear fuel can meet years of energy needs, making strategic reserves practical. Coal's bulk makes equivalent stockpiling impractical.
Small volumes of nuclear fuel can meet years of energy needs, making strategic reserves practical. Coal's bulk makes equivalent stockpiling impractical.

toLevel5.sentence: The energy density advantage of nuclear over chemical fuels is approximately {{blank:1}} because the {{blank:2}} is much stronger than electromagnetic forces at relevant scales.

1.correctExplanation: The million-fold energy advantage directly reflects the strength difference between nuclear and electromagnetic forces at their respective interaction distances.

distractors.explanation: The million-fold energy advantage directly reflects the strength difference between nuclear and electromagnetic forces at their respective interaction distances.
The million-fold energy advantage directly reflects the strength difference between nuclear and electromagnetic forces at their respective interaction distances.

toLevel5.sentence: For equivalent annual electricity generation, a nuclear plant needs {{blank:1}} of uranium versus {{blank:2}} of coal.

1.correctExplanation: A 1 GW plant uses about 30 tonnes of uranium/year versus several million tonnes of coal, reflecting the energy density difference.

distractors.explanation: A 1 GW plant uses about 30 tonnes of uranium/year versus several million tonnes of coal, reflecting the energy density difference.
